title: Print, Two Designs for Letter "T" with Red Matrix Layer, for "Vivo in Typo" Poster, 2008
title_raw: Two Designs for Letter "T" with Red Matrix Layer, for "Vivo in Typo" Poster
provenance: Philippe Apeloig to Cooper Hewitt, June 2014
description: Two letter "T"s oriented horizontally, printed in black (left) and red (right) on white ground. Overprinted color fades from left to right with ombre effect. Letters comprised of same series of dots and dashes, but italicized.
justification: In 2006 Philippe Apeloig designed a poster for an installation of his posters at Espace Topographie de l’Art in Paris, entitled Vivo in Typo.  A group of nineteen preparatory drawings and prints document Apeloig’s design process for creating Vivo in Typo, documenting the evolution of this poster design.  Apeloig’s compositional studies are worked out in pen and ink by hand.  On one of these sheets, he also jots down his thoughts for the matrix (foundational elements) out of which the poster will be created.  The matrix is composed of different punctuation marks-- dashes, semicolons, and vertical bars.  The digital prints highlight moments in the designer’s computer process.  Using the computer, Apeloig or a member of his studio built up layers of markings, applying different kernings or adjustments to the spacing of individual letter forms and then laid these examples one on top of another. gallery_text: Apeloig’s working method moves seamlessly between hand drawings and computer-generated graphics. For the Vivo in Typo poster, advertising an exhibition of his own work, he began with pen and ink drawings to wrestle with different lettering layouts and turned to the computer to compose a system of punctuation marks that became the matrix from which the letters would emerge. The digital prints on view show how he built up, through multiple layers of marks with varied spacing and colored inks, a rich textural and vibrating surface. For Apeloig, typography is not only a tool, but the material itself.
